message.content:
Research how to programmatically manipulate Adobe Premiere Pro timelines. Find information about:
1. ExtendScript/JSX APIs for timeline manipulation
2. How to add clips to timeline with specific in/out points
3. How to set clip colors/labels programmatically
4. How to create markers and annotations
5. How to organize clips into bins/folders
6. Working with sequences and nested sequences

Focus on the technical implementation of adding, coloring, and organizing clips in Premiere Pro.

Premiere Pro scripting add clips to timeline in out points ExtendScript
Premiere Pro ExtendScript clip label colors programmatically

content.content:
Web search results for query: "Premiere Pro scripting add clips to timeline in out points ExtendScript"

Links: [{"title":"Solved: Editing clips with ExtendScript - Adobe Product Community - 9056625","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro/editing-clips-with-extendscript/td-p/9056625"},{"title":"Premiere Pro Scripting: Set In and Out Points of Clip","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/premiere-pro-scripting-set-in-and-out-points-of-clip/td-p/10490225"},{"title":"Solved: Premiere Pro Scripting ExtendScript question - Adobe Product Community - 13379442","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/premiere-pro-scripting-extendscript-question/td-p/13379442"},{"title":"How to Nest a Sequence using ExtendScript in Premiere Pro","url":"https://vakago-tools.com/how-to-nest-a-sequence-using-extendscript-in-premiere-pro/"},{"title":"Using Adobe ExtendScript to Automate Video Editing in Premiere Pro","url":"https://metadesignsolutions.com/using-adobe-extendscript-to-automate-video-editing-in-premiere-pro/"},{"title":"Solved: Selected clip in timeline? - Adobe Product Community - 8233928","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/selected-clip-in-timeline/td-p/8233928"},{"title":"Solved: Re: Premiere Pro Scripting ExtendScript question - Adobe Support Community - 13379442","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/premiere-pro-scripting-extendscript-question/m-p/13380994"},{"title":"Having fun with the Active Sequence, Mute Tracks, Place Clips - PremiereOnScript","url":"https://premiereonscript.com/log-11/"},{"title":"Solved: Selected clip in timeline? - Adobe Support Community - 8233928","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/selected-clip-in-timeline/m-p/8233928"},{"title":"Re: Premiere Pro Scripting: Set In and Out Points of Clip","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/premiere-pro-scripting-set-in-and-out-points-of-clip/m-p/10490227"}]

Based on my search results, here's what I found about adding clips to the timeline with in/out points using ExtendScript in Adobe Premiere Pro:

## Key Methods for Adding Clips with In/Out Points

### Setting In/Out Points Before Adding to Timeline

The recommended approach is to set the in/out points of the projectItem before you insert a clip into the sequence.(no content)The `setInPoint()` and `setOutPoint()` methods work in CC 2019 and later, but don't exist for project items in CC 2017.

### Adding Clips to Timeline

Overwriting a clip will place that clip in the timeline wherever you specify, with no regards to what was there before it. It will not shift anything around, it will just place it on top and delete whatever was there before it. This can be accomplished through `app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].overwriteClip(clip, timecode in seconds)`.(no content)If you would like to place the clip at the current player position, you can use:
```javascript
var playerPosition = app.project.activeSequence.getPlayerPosition();
app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].overwriteClip(clip, playerPosition.seconds)
```
Note the `.seconds` after the player position timecode - this converts the time from TICKS to SECONDS.

### Getting In/Out Points from Selected Clips

You can loop through a trackItemCollection and check for the `isSelected()` property. It returns a boolean, and if true, you can get the trackItem's both inPoint and outPoint.

### Alternative Approaches

Mimicking in-timeline editing is not possible through ExtendScript as of today, but you can try to mimic classical 3-point editing through a script if your marker information is of such quality that you can calculate the time values for the source clips.(no content)One workaround is to select the current clip, create a subclip of it with the new in point, move it to a specific bin in the projects, then overwrite it on the track right next to the last clip.(no content)Another option is to perform editing outside of Premiere with shell scripts and create FCP XML sequences that you can import to Premiere afterwards.

### Using createSubClip()

With `createSubClip()` you can split a piece of imported footage into as many sections as you want, and you can set In and Out points for each of them separately.

### Nesting/Subsequences

When working with sequences, you need to store the current inPoint and outPoint of the active sequence if you plan to change them, then get the start and end times of the selection to set new inPoint and outPoint values.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Labels PPro 2 - aescripts.com","url":"https://aescripts.com/labels-ppro/"},{"title":"Quick Tip: Using Label Colors to Manage Premiere Pro Projects","url":"https://www.premiumbeat.com/blog/using-clip-colors-premiere-pro/"},{"title":"Solved: Re: Change label color with API in Premiere - Adobe Product Community - 12585081","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/change-label-color-with-api-in-premiere/m-p/12585126"},{"title":"Premiere Pro / Extendscript API Effect Component ...","url":"https://premiereonscript.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/Premiere-v12-Effect-Documentation.pdf"},{"title":"Samples/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx at master · Adobe-CEP/Samples","url":"https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/blob/master/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx"},{"title":"Re: Access Premiere clip colors - Adobe Community","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro/access-premiere-clip-colors/m-p/8629415"},{"title":"Automatize changing color label of clips in timeline : Node.js","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/automatize-changing-color-label-of-clips-in-timeline-node-js/m-p/12702760"},{"title":"Using Adobe ExtendScript to Automate Video Editing in Premiere Pro","url":"https://metadesignsolutions.com/using-adobe-extendscript-to-automate-video-editing-in-premiere-pro/"},{"title":"Cannot get label color from script","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/cannot-get-label-color-from-script/m-p/14842634"},{"title":"(Premiere) Why aren’t my unsynced clips colored?","url":"https://support.maxon.net/hc/en-us/articles/232058347--Premiere-Why-aren-t-my-unsynced-clips-colored"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about programmatically changing clip label colors in Premiere Pro using ExtendScript:

## Key Findings

### API Limitations
One can only change the label color of projectItems; there's no API to do so, for trackItems. This is an important limitation when working with ExtendScript in Premiere Pro.

Users working with lots of Mogrts have asked about the possibility to change their label color through Extendscript commands, even using QE. However, adding a label color element to an existing .mogrt is not possible.

### Project Settings Consideration
Only items that have a source can be labeled, such as video, image, and sound layers. Also, the "Display the project item name and label color for all instances" setting has to be enabled in the project for it to work.(no content)This results in both Item and Layer colors being the same - changing color in the timeline automatically changes the color in the Project Panel. The label colors are in synch for layers and items.

### How to Enable Global Color Syncing
Navigate to File > Project Settings > General and tick the check box labeled "Display the project item name and label color for all instances." Now the color of the clip in the project browser will update to all instances of the clip in the project.

### Third-Party Tools
Labels PPro allows you to easily set label colors and select label groups with a single click. Select a clip or a project item and pick a color. Or better yet, select a bunch and apply the same label color to all of them.

### ExtendScript General Capabilities
Adobe ExtendScript is a JavaScript-based scripting language that allows developers to automate tasks in Premiere Pro. By leveraging ExtendScript, editors can automate video editing workflows, reduce manual work, and improve efficiency.

## Summary
The Premiere Pro ExtendScript API allows changing label colors on **project items** (clips in the Project Panel), but there is no direct API for changing label colors on **track items** (clips on the timeline). To work around this, you can enable the project setting to sync label colors across all instances of a clip.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Adobe Premiere Pro ExtendScript JSX API timeline manipulation 2024 2025"

Links: [{"title":"Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/"},{"title":"Offline Docs - Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/print_page/"},{"title":"Samples/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx at master · Adobe-CEP/Samples","url":"https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/blob/master/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx"},{"title":"Using Adobe ExtendScript to Automate Video Editing in Premiere Pro","url":"https://metadesignsolutions.com/using-adobe-extendscript-to-automate-video-editing-in-premiere-pro/"},{"title":"Overview - Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/introduction/extendscript-overview/"},{"title":"Solved: How do you run JSX scripts in Premiere Pro 2024 ma... - Adobe Product Community - 14533504","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/how-do-you-run-jsx-scripts-in-premiere-pro-2024-macos/m-p/14533504"},{"title":"Request for Timeline Editing API Support (Clip Tra... - Adobe Product Community - 15624626","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-ideas/request-for-timeline-editing-api-support-clip-track-movement-flattening/idc-p/15625392"},{"title":"Adobe Premiere Pro MCP Server by hetpatel-11 | PulseMCP","url":"https://www.pulsemcp.com/servers/adobe-premiere-pro"},{"title":"Solved: ExtendScript Toolkit and Premiere Pro? - Adobe Product Community - 8613271","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/extendscript-toolkit-and-premiere-pro/m-p/8613271"},{"title":"Solved: Re: Create a premiere pro extension in 2023 - Adobe Product Community - 14099347","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/create-a-premiere-pro-extension-in-2023/m-p/14099881"}]

Here are the search results for Adobe Premiere Pro ExtendScript JSX API timeline manipulation:

## Key Findings

### Platform Transition
As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

### ExtendScript API Capabilities
Premiere Pro provides an ExtendScript API, allowing for the access and manipulation of most project elements, including metadata, exporting and rendering options.

The API provides access to timeline elements such as:
New API to move a trackItem, and new APIs to set the disabled state of a trackItem.

### Timeline Manipulation Limitations
There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks. Premiere Pro no longer includes a keyboard mappable command like Move Clip Up/Down Between Tracks, meaning even UI automation cannot rely on a universal shortcut. The function in QE appears to be stubbed or deprecated without a documented replacement. This means that currently there is no programmatic way to manipulate clip positions across video tracks while preserving edit timing.

### Development Environment
Executing scripts from within CEP panels is the recommended approach.(no content)ExtendScript Toolkit (ESTK) is no longer updated by Adobe; the recommended debugging environment for ExtendScript is Microsoft Visual Studio Code, with Adobe's ExtendScript debugging extension.(no content)There is no way to execute a jsx script directly, unless you run it with VS Code and the Debugger.

### Running JSX Scripts
To begin scripting in Premiere Pro using ExtendScript, follow these steps: Open Premiere Pro, go to Window → Utilities → Scripts, right-click on User Scripts → Reveal in Finder/Explorer, and place your .jsx scripts in this folder for easy access.

### Resources
- **Official Documentation**: https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/
- **PProPanel Sample**: The PProPanel sample exercises Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API at https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel.
- Microsoft Visual Studio Code + the ExtendScript Debugger extension are the supported development environment.

### Recent Developments
Released in July 2025, there's an MCP Server that integrates with Adobe Premiere Pro through ExtendScript and UXP plugin communication to enable natural language video editing commands for project management, media import, timeline operations, effects application, and rendering workflows.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.content:
Web search results for query: "Premiere Pro ExtendScript markers createProjectItemMarker addMarker API"

Web search error: unavailable

I apologize, but the web search tool is currently unavailable. However, I can share some information from my existing knowledge about working with markers in Premiere Pro using ExtendScript:

## Premiere Pro ExtendScript Markers API

In Adobe Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API, you can work with markers through the following approaches:

### Sequence Markers
For sequence markers, you can use:
- `sequence.markers` - Returns a MarkerCollection object
- `markers.createMarker(time)` - Creates a new marker at the specified time

### Clip/Project Item Markers
For clip markers (markers on project items/source clips):
- `projectItem.getMarkers()` - Returns the markers for a project item
- `markers.createMarker(time)` - Creates a marker at the specified time position

### Marker Properties
Once you have a marker object, you can set properties like:
- `marker.name` - The marker name
- `marker.comments` - Comments/notes for the marker
- `marker.type` - The type of marker
- `marker.start` - Start time (Time object)
- `marker.end` - End time (Time object)

### Example Code
```javascript
// Get active sequence
var seq = app.project.activeSequence;

// Create a marker at 5 seconds
var newMarker = seq.markers.createMarker(5.0);
newMarker.name = "My Marker";
newMarker.comments = "This is a comment";
```

If you need the most up-to-date or specific documentation, I'd recommend checking:
1. The official Adobe Premiere Pro Scripting Guide
2. Adobe's ExtendScript API reference
3. The Adobe Developer forums

Would you like me to try the search again later, or do you have any specific questions about the markers API that I might be able to help with from my existing knowledge?


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"How to Nest a Sequence using ExtendScript in Premiere Pro","url":"https://vakago-tools.com/how-to-nest-a-sequence-using-extendscript-in-premiere-pro/"},{"title":"ExtendScript: Is it possible to insert a MultiCam Source -- nested -- into active sequence","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/extendscript-is-it-possible-to-insert-a-multicam-source-nested-into-active-sequence/m-p/11062852"},{"title":"Offline Docs - Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/print_page/"},{"title":"Samples/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx at master · Adobe-CEP/Samples","url":"https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/blob/master/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx"},{"title":"Having fun with the Active Sequence, Mute Tracks, Place Clips - PremiereOnScript","url":"https://premiereonscript.com/log-11/"},{"title":"Solved: Editing clips with ExtendScript - Adobe Product Community - 9056625","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro/editing-clips-with-extendscript/td-p/9056625"},{"title":"Sequence object - Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/sequence/sequence/"},{"title":"Solved: Premiere to media encoder with extendscript - Adobe Product Community - 9804646","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/premiere-to-media-encoder-with-extendscript/td-p/9804646"},{"title":"PremiereOnScript - Page 2 of 3 - Use Scripting within Adobe Premiere Pro for for a more efficient, automated, and standardized workflow.","url":"https://premiereonscript.com/page/2/"},{"title":"ExtendScript - overwriteClip or insertClip - don't nest when sequence item","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/extendscript-overwriteclip-or-insertclip-don-t-nest-when-sequence-item/td-p/11373804"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Premiere Pro ExtendScript for sequence nesting and creating sequences from clips:

## Key Findings

### Nesting Sequences in Premiere Pro ExtendScript

While the Premiere Pro scripting API does not natively offer a "nest" function, you can still use ExtendScript to accomplish this task by writing your own function to do so.(no content)This can be done by making use of the `createSubsequence()` method to mimic the nest functionality.

### The `createSubsequence()` Method

The `createSubsequence()` method returns the newly-created Sequence object. However, this is not the same as nesting. The newly-created sequence is not inserted back into the original sequence. To nest, see the example function below.

### Example Nesting Function

The official Premiere Pro Scripting Guide provides an example `nestSelection()` function that demonstrates how to nest clips:

The function gets the active sequence and selection, stores the original in/out points, sets the sequence in/out points to match the selection boundaries, creates a subsequence using `createSubsequence(true)`, then overwrites the clip position with the nested sequence's projectItem.

### Inserting Clips into Sequences

Inserting a clip can be accomplished through `app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].insertClip(clip, timecode in seconds)`.(no content)Overwriting a clip can be accomplished through `app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].overwriteClip(clip, timecode in seconds)`.

### Limitations

There's no API to control whether nesting occurs or not when using `insertClip` or `overwriteClip` with sequence ProjectItems.

You can insert a multi-cam sequence, but only as individual clips — there's a limitation with multi-cam sequences not being inserted as nested sequences via the API.

### Additional Notes

No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered, once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

results:
Based on the search results, here's information about Premiere Pro ExtendScript for sequence nesting and creating sequences from clips:

## Key Findings

### Nesting Sequences in Premiere Pro ExtendScript

While the Premiere Pro scripting API does not natively offer a "nest" function, you can still use ExtendScript to accomplish this task by writing your own function to do so.(no content)This can be done by making use of the `createSubsequence()` method to mimic the nest functionality.

### The `createSubsequence()` Method

The `createSubsequence()` method returns the newly-created Sequence object. However, this is not the same as nesting. The newly-created sequence is not inserted back into the original sequence. To nest, see the example function below.

### Example Nesting Function

The official Premiere Pro Scripting Guide provides an example `nestSelection()` function that demonstrates how to nest clips:

The function gets the active sequence and selection, stores the original in/out points, sets the sequence in/out points to match the selection boundaries, creates a subsequence using `createSubsequence(true)`, then overwrites the clip position with the nested sequence's projectItem.

### Inserting Clips into Sequences

Inserting a clip can be accomplished through `app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].insertClip(clip, timecode in seconds)`.(no content)Overwriting a clip can be accomplished through `app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].overwriteClip(clip, timecode in seconds)`.

### Limitations

There's no API to control whether nesting occurs or not when using `insertClip` or `overwriteClip` with sequence ProjectItems.

You can insert a multi-cam sequence, but only as individual clips — there's a limitation with multi-cam sequences not being inserted as nested sequences via the API.

### Additional Notes

No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered, once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

# Premiere Pro Scripting Guide - API Overview

Based on the documentation index provided, here's what's available for ExtendScript API development:

## Available Documentation Structure

The guide organizes scripting capabilities into several key categories:

**Sequence & Timeline Control:**
- "Sequence object" for timeline manipulation
- "Track object" for track-level operations
- "TrackItem object" for individual clip management
- "Component object" and "ComponentParam object" for effects/settings

**Clip Management:**
The navigation menu references both "TrackItem object" and "ProjectItem object," suggesting methods exist for working with clips, though specific method names (insertClip, overwriteClip) aren't detailed in this index.

**Organization:**
- "Project object" for project-level operations
- Collection objects including "TrackItemCollection" and "ProjectItemCollection" for batch operations
- References to "MarkerCollection object" for marker functionality

**Additional Resources:**
- "Marker object" for marker creation and management
- "Metadata object" for property manipulation
- "Time object" for temporal parameters

## Important Note

The guide explicitly states: *"As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP."* ExtendScript integrations remain supported through September 2026, but developers should consider migrating to the UXP framework for new projects.

For detailed method signatures and implementation specifics, you'd need to access the individual object documentation pages referenced in the menu structure.

content.content:
# TrackItem Methods and Properties for Clip Manipulation

Based on the Premiere Pro Scripting Guide documentation, here are the key TrackItem attributes and methods for clip manipulation:

## Properties for In/Out Points and Positioning

- **inPoint**: "The in point set on the source for this trackItem instance, relative to the beginning of the source" (Time object, read/write)
- **outPoint**: "The out point set on the source for this TrackItem instance, relative to the beginning of the source" (Time object, read/write)
- **start**: Visible start time in sequence (Time object, read/write)
- **end**: Visible end time in sequence (Time object, read/write)
- **duration**: Length of the trackItem (Time object, read-only)

## Methods for Clip Manipulation

- **move(newInPoint)**: Shifts the track item's starting point by a specified time duration
- **getSpeed()**: Returns the speed multiplier applied to the clip
- **isSpeedReversed()**: Indicates whether the clip is reversed (returns 1 or 0)
- **remove(inRipple, inAlignToVideo)**: Removes the clip from the track
- **setSelected(state, updateUI)**: Sets the clip's selection state
- **disabled**: Boolean property controlling whether the clip is enabled or disabled

## Note on Label Colors

The documentation provided does not include information about label color properties or methods for TrackItem objects.

- **start**: Visible start time in sequence (Time object, read/write)
- **end**: Visible end time in sequence (Time object, read/write)

## Methods for Clip Manipulation

- **move(newInPoint)**: Shifts the track item's starting point by a specified time duration
- **getSpeed()**: Returns the speed multiplier applied to the clip
- **isSpeedReversed()**: Indicates whether the clip is reversed (returns 1 or 0)

- **disabled**: Boolean property controlling whether the clip is enabled or disabled

## Note on Label Colors

The documentation provided does not include information about label color properties or methods for TrackItem objects.

content.content:
# Sequence Object Methods and Properties

## Key Properties

**Track Management:**
- `audioTracks` - Collection of audio Track objects
- `videoTracks` - Collection of video Track objects

**Timing & Display:**
- `timebase` - "The number of ticks per frame in the sequence"
- `zeroPoint` - Starting time in ticks
- `end` - End time in ticks

**Identification:**
- `name` - Sequence identifier (read/write)
- `sequenceID` - "Unique identifier assigned to this sequence...in the form of `xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx`"

**Metadata:**
- `markers` - MarkerCollection of sequence markers
- `projectItem` - Associated ProjectItem object

## Essential Methods for Clip Manipulation

**Inserting/Overwriting Clips:**
- `insertClip()` - "Inserts a clip into the sequence, on the specified video and audio tracks"
- `overwriteClip()` - "Inserts a clip into the sequence, _overwriting existing clips_"

**Subsequence Creation:**
- `createSubsequence()` - "Creates a new sequence, from the in and out point, which is a sub-sequence"

**Selection Management:**
- `getSelection()` - Returns selected TrackItem objects in temporal order
- `linkSelection()` - Links selected video/audio clips
- `unlinkSelection()` - Unlinks selected clips

**Timeline Control:**
- `setInPoint()`, `setOutPoint()` - Mark sequence boundaries
- `setPlayerPosition()` - Position the Current Time Indicator
- `setWorkAreaInPoint()`, `setWorkAreaOutPoint()` - Define work area

- `projectItem` - Associated ProjectItem object

## Essential Methods for Clip Manipulation

**Subsequence Creation:**
- `createSubsequence()` - "Creates a new sequence, from the in and out point, which is a sub-sequence"

**Selection Management:**
- `getSelection()` - Returns selected TrackItem objects in temporal order
- `linkSelection()` - Links selected video/audio clips
- `unlinkSelection()` - Unlinks selected clips

**Timeline Control:**
- `setInPoint()`, `setOutPoint()` - Mark sequence boundaries
- `setPlayerPosition()` - Position the Current Time Indicator
- `setWorkAreaInPoint()`, `setWorkAreaOutPoint()` - Define work area

content.content:
# Marker Object: Methods and Properties

## Attributes

The Marker object includes six key properties:

1. **Marker.comments** — A read/write string containing "the comments within the marker"
2. **Marker.end** — A Time object marking "the value of the ending of the marker" (read/write)
3. **Marker.guid** — A read-only string representing "the unique identifier of the marker"
4. **Marker.name** — A read/write string for "the name of the marker"
5. **Marker.start** — A Time object for "the value of the beginning of the marker" (read/write)
6. **Marker.type** — A read-only string indicating marker type (Comment, Chapter, Segmentation, or WebLink)

## Methods

The object provides eight methods for manipulation:

**Type Assignment Methods:**
- `setTypeAsChapter()` — Converts marker to Chapter type
- `setTypeAsComment()` — Converts marker to Comment type
- `setTypeAsSegmentation()` — Converts marker to Segmentation type
- `setTypeAsWebLink()` — Converts marker to WebLink type

**Color and Link Methods:**
- `setColorByIndex(colorIndex, markerIndex)` — Applies color (0-7 indices representing Green through Cyan)
- `getColorByIndex(index)` — Retrieves the color index
- `getWebLinkURL()` — Returns the marker's URL field
- `getWebLinkFrameTarget()` — Retrieves the frame target from WebLink markers

2. **Marker.end** — A Time object marking "the value of the ending of the marker" (read/write)
3. **Marker.guid** — A read-only string representing "the unique identifier of the marker"
4. **Marker.name** — A read/write string for "the name of the marker"
5. **Marker.start** — A Time object for "the value of the beginning of the marker" (read/write)
6. **Marker.type** — A read-only string indicating marker type (Comment, Chapter, Segmentation, or WebLink)

## Methods

**Type Assignment Methods:**
- `setTypeAsChapter()` — Converts marker to Chapter type
- `setTypeAsComment()` — Converts marker to Comment type
- `setTypeAsSegmentation()` — Converts marker to Segmentation type
- `setTypeAsWebLink()` — Converts marker to WebLink type

**Color and Link Methods:**
- `setColorByIndex(colorIndex, markerIndex)` — Applies color (0-7 indices representing Green through Cyan)
- `getColorByIndex(index)` — Retrieves the color index
- `getWebLinkURL()` — Returns the marker's URL field
- `getWebLinkFrameTarget()` — Retrieves the frame target from WebLink markers

content.content:
# ProjectItem Methods: Label Colors, Bins, Markers, and Clip Properties

## Color Label Management

**setColorLabel()** allows you to assign a color label to a project item. The method accepts an integer parameter corresponding to predefined colors (0-15), ranging from Violet through Yellow. This functionality enables visual organization within the project.

**getColorLabel()** retrieves the currently assigned color label, returning an integer value that maps to one of the 16 available colors.

## Bin Operations

**createBin()** generates a new empty bin within a project item, accepting a string name parameter. The method returns a project item representing the newly created bin if successful.

**renameBin()** modifies an existing bin's name by accepting a new name string and returning 0 upon successful completion.

**moveBin()** relocates a project item into a different parent bin, requiring the target bin's project item as a parameter.

**deleteBin()** removes a bin and its entire contents from the project, returning 0 when deletion succeeds.

## Marker and Clip Information

**getMarkers()** retrieves the MarkerCollection object associated with a project item, providing read-only access to all markers.

## Clip Properties

Additional methods manage clip characteristics: **setFootageInterpretation()** configures interpretation settings, **setInPoint()** and **setOutPoint()** establish media boundaries, and **getFootageInterpretation()** returns detailed structural data about alpha usage, field type, frame rate, and pixel aspect ratio.

# ProjectItem Methods: Label Colors, Bins, Markers, and Clip Properties

## Color Label Management

**setColorLabel()** allows you to assign a color label to a project item. The method accepts an integer parameter corresponding to predefined colors (0-15), ranging from Violet through Yellow. This functionality enables visual organization within the project.

**getColorLabel()** retrieves the currently assigned color label, returning an integer value that maps to one of the 16 available colors.

## Bin Operations

**createBin()** generates a new empty bin within a project item, accepting a string name parameter. The method returns a project item representing the newly created bin if successful.

**renameBin()** modifies an existing bin's name by accepting a new name string and returning 0 upon successful completion.

**moveBin()** relocates a project item into a different parent bin, requiring the target bin's project item as a parameter.

**deleteBin()** removes a bin and its entire contents from the project, returning 0 when deletion succeeds.

## Marker and Clip Information

**getMarkers()** retrieves the MarkerCollection object associated with a project item, providing read-only access to all markers.

## Clip Properties

Additional methods manage clip characteristics: **setFootageInterpretation()** configures interpretation settings, **setInPoint()** and **setOutPoint()** establish media boundaries, and **getFootageInterpretation()** returns detailed structural data about alpha usage, field type, frame rate, and pixel aspect ratio.

content.content:
# MarkerCollection Methods

The MarkerCollection object provides several methods for managing markers in Premiere Pro sequences and project items:

## Key Methods

**createMarker()** - "Create a new Marker object on a project item or a sequence." This method accepts a float parameter representing time in seconds where the marker should be positioned, and returns a Marker object if successful.

**deleteMarker()** - Removes a specified marker from the collection, accepting a Marker object as a parameter and returning a boolean value.

**getFirstMarker()** - "Retrieve the first marker object, sorted by time in seconds, on a given project item or sequence," returning either a Marker object or undefined.

**getLastMarker()** - Obtains the final marker sorted chronologically, also returning a Marker object or undefined.

**getNextMarker()** - "Get the next available marker, sorted by seconds, starting from a given one," requiring a current Marker object as input.

**getPrevMarker()** - Retrieves the previous marker in chronological sequence from a starting Marker object.

## Additional Property

**numMarkers** - "The count of marker objects in the project item or sequence," provided as a read-only integer attribute.

**deleteMarker()** - Removes a specified marker from the collection, accepting a Marker object as a parameter and returning a boolean value.

**getFirstMarker()** - "Retrieve the first marker object, sorted by time in seconds, on a given project item or sequence," returning either a Marker object or undefined.

**getLastMarker()** - Obtains the final marker sorted chronologically, also returning a Marker object or undefined.

**getNextMarker()** - "Get the next available marker, sorted by seconds, starting from a given one," requiring a current Marker object as input.

**getPrevMarker()** - Retrieves the previous marker in chronological sequence from a starting Marker object.

## Additional Property

**numMarkers** - "The count of marker objects in the project item or sequence," provided as a read-only integer attribute.

PremiereOnScript","url":"https://premiereonscript.com/log-11/"},{"title":"Solved: ExtendScript - overwriteClip or insertClip - don't... - Adobe Product Community - 11373804","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/extendscript-overwriteclip-or-insertclip-don-t-nest-when-sequence-item/td-p/11373804"},{"title":"Samples/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx at master · Adobe-CEP/Samples","url":"https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/blob/master/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx"},{"title":"Offline Docs - Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/print_page/"},{"title":"Solved: ExtendScript: Can I get a trackItem reference when... - Adobe Product Community - 10885309","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/extendscript-can-i-get-a-trackitem-reference-when-using-track-insertclip-track-overwriteclip/td-p/10885309"},{"title":"Solved: Editing clips with ExtendScript - Adobe Product Community - 9056625","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro/editing-clips-with-extendscript/td-p/9056625"},{"title":"Solved: ExtendScript: videoTrack.insertClip for video or a... - Adobe Support Community - 11145379","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro/extendscript-videotrack-insertclip-for-video-or-audio-only/td-p/11145379"},{"title":"How to Nest a Sequence using ExtendScript in Premiere Pro","url":"https://vakago-tools.com/how-to-nest-a-sequence-using-extendscript-in-premiere-pro/"},{"title":"Parameter types for Track.insertClip and Track.overwriteClip?","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/parameter-types-for-track-insertclip-and-track-overwriteclip/m-p/9049723"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the Premiere Pro ExtendScript `insertClip` and `overwriteClip` method syntax and parameters:

## Sequence-level Methods

### insertClip

The syntax is:
```javascript
app.project.sequences[index].insertClip(projectItem, time, vTrackIndex, aTrackIndex)
```
This inserts a clip into the sequence, on the specified video and audio tracks, at the specified time. Returns a boolean; true if successful.

### overwriteClip

The syntax is:
```javascript
app.project.sequences[index].overwriteClip(projectItem, time, vTrackIndex, aTrackIndex)
```
This inserts a clip into the sequence, overwriting existing clips, on the specified video and audio tracks, at the specified time.

## Track-level Methods

For Track-level access, you can use:
```javascript
app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].insertClip(clip, timecode in seconds);
```
Overwriting a clip will place that clip in the timeline wherever you specify, with no regards to what was there before it.

### Example from Adobe GitHub:

```javascript
var newClip = seq.insertClip(first, time, (seq.videoTracks.numTracks - 1), (seq.audioTracks.numTracks - 1));
```


## Key Behaviors and Quirks

It doesn't seem to matter whether you choose the target sequence's videoTracks or audioTracks. Executing insertClip/overwriteClip always carries all picture and sound tracks from source clip to sequence.(no content)It does matter which track layer is chosen. Choosing videoTracks[0] or audioTracks[0] means a source clip with 1 picture track and 2 sound tracks will route to V1 and A1/A2 on the record side.(no content)The 'overwriteClip' method 'returns 0 if successful' according to the documentation, rather than returning the resulting trackItem.

## Important Note

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

input.prompt: Extract code examples for insertClip, overwriteClip, working with tracks, and placing clips on timeline
Extract the complete code example for nesting sequences using ExtendScript including createSubsequence method

content.content:
# Code Examples from PremiereOnScript

## Muting Tracks

The article provides a toggle example:

```javascript
if(activeSeq.videoTracks[1].isMuted() == true){
   activeSeq.videoTracks[1].setMute(false)
}else{
   activeSeq.videoTracks[1].setMute(true);
}
```

This checks track status using `.isMuted()` and uses `.setMute()` to change it.

## Inserting Clips

"will place that clip in at the time specified, and then shift the previously placed clips around it."

```javascript
app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].insertClip(clip, timecode in seconds);
```

## Overwriting Clips

"will place that clip in the timeline wherever you specify, with no regards to what was there before it."

```javascript
app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].overwriteClip(clip, timecode in seconds);
```

## Placing at Player Position

```javascript
var playerPosition = app.project.activeSequence.getPlayerPosition();
app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].overwriteClip(clip, playerPosition.seconds)
```

**Key detail:** The `.seconds` property converts timecode "from TICKS to SECONDS."

toolUseResult.result:
# Code Examples from PremiereOnScript

## Muting Tracks

The article provides a toggle example:

```javascript
if(activeSeq.videoTracks[1].isMuted() == true){
   activeSeq.videoTracks[1].setMute(false)
}else{
   activeSeq.videoTracks[1].setMute(true);
}
```

This checks track status using `.isMuted()` and uses `.setMute()` to change it.

## Inserting Clips

"will place that clip in at the time specified, and then shift the previously placed clips around it."

```javascript
app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].insertClip(clip, timecode in seconds);
```

## Overwriting Clips

"will place that clip in the timeline wherever you specify, with no regards to what was there before it."

```javascript
app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].overwriteClip(clip, timecode in seconds);
```

## Placing at Player Position

```javascript
var playerPosition = app.project.activeSequence.getPlayerPosition();
app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[x].overwriteClip(clip, playerPosition.seconds)
```

**Key detail:** The `.seconds` property converts timecode "from TICKS to SECONDS."

input.query: Premiere Pro ExtendScript project rootItem children iterate clips bins example

input.prompt:
Extract complete information about:
1. Track object methods (insertClip, overwriteClip parameters)
2. ProjectItem colorLabel methods
3. Creating and organizing bins
4. Complete code examples for timeline manipulation

content.content:
# Premiere Pro ExtendScript API Reference Guide

## 1. Track Object Methods

### insertClip()
"Adds a 'clip' (media segment from a ProjectItem object) to the track, at the specified time. Media will be inserted, at that time."

**Parameters:**
- `projectItem` - ProjectItem object
- `time` - String (in ticks)
- `vTrackIndex` - Integer (zero-based video track index)
- `aTrackIndex` - Integer (zero-based audio track index)

### overwriteClip()
"Adds a 'clip' (media segment from a ProjectItem object) to the track, at the specified time. This will overwrite any existing media, at that time."

**Parameters:**
- `projectItem` - ProjectItem object
- `time` - String (in ticks)

Returns `true` if successful.

---

## 2. ProjectItem Color Label Methods

### getColorLabel()
Returns an integer (0-15) representing color assignments:
- 0 = Violet through 15 = Yellow

### setColorLabel()
`setColorLabel(labelColor)` accepts an integer matching the enumeration above. Returns `0` if successful.

---

## 3. Creating and Organizing Bins

### Creating Bins
Use "createBin(name)" on a ProjectItem. Returns a new bin ProjectItem or `0` if unsuccessful.

### Creating Smart Bins
Use "createSmartBin(name, queryString)" for search-based organization.

### Renaming Bins
"renameBin(newName)" modifies bin names. Returns `0` upon success.

### Moving Bins
"moveBin(newParentBinProjectItem)" relocates bins hierarchically.

### Deleting Bins
"deleteBin()" removes bins and their contents, returning `0` on success.

---

## 4. Timeline Manipulation Code Examples

### Insert Clip Example
```javascript
var sequence = app.project.activeSequence;
var projectItem = app.project.rootItem.children[0];
var time = new Time();
time.seconds = 5;

sequence.insertClip(projectItem, time, 0, 0); // Insert on V1, A1
```

### Overwrite Clip Example
```javascript
var sequence = app.project.activeSequence;
sequence.overwriteClip(projectItem, 10, 1, 1); // At 10 seconds
```

### Bin Organization Example
```javascript
var rootBin = app.project.rootItem;
var mediaBin = rootBin.createBin("Media Clips");
mediaBin.createBin("B-Roll");
mediaBin.createBin("Graphics");
```

### Track Muting Example
```javascript
var track = app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[0];
if (!track.isMuted()) {
    track.setMute(1);
}
```

## 1. Track Object Methods

### insertClip()

### overwriteClip()

**Parameters:**

Returns `true` if successful.

---

## 2. ProjectItem Color Label Methods

- 0 = Violet through 15 = Yellow

### setColorLabel()
`setColorLabel(labelColor)` accepts an integer matching the enumeration above. Returns `0` if successful.

---

## 3. Creating and Organizing Bins

### Creating Bins

### Creating Smart Bins

### Renaming Bins
"renameBin(newName)" modifies bin names. Returns `0` upon success.

### Moving Bins

### Deleting Bins

---

## 4. Timeline Manipulation Code Examples

### Insert Clip Example

```javascript
var track = app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[0];
if (!track.isMuted()) {

}
```

ExtendScript: How to create a sequence directly to a specific bin?
Creating Bins, Sequences, and Moving them Around - PremiereOnScript

input.prompt: Extract complete code examples for creating bins, sequences, and moving items around in Premiere Pro

content.content:
# Code Examples from "Creating Bins, Sequences, and Moving them Around"

Based on the article content provided, I cannot extract complete code examples, as **the web page does not contain actual code snippets** in the visible text.

## What the Article Discusses

The tutorial covers three essential methods:

1. **createBin()** — Creates new bins in Premiere Pro projects
2. **moveBin()** — Moves project items and changes their parent location
3. **createNewSequence()** — Creates sequences (though the author notes this requires user interaction)

## Key Takeaways Mentioned

- The `moveBin()` function "moves any project item, not just bins. It technically is not moving a bin,
but changing the parent of the item."
- For better sequence creation, the author recommends using `qe.project.newSequence()` instead, which requires working with `.sqpresets` files
- The article references sample code on GitHub but doesn't display it directly on the page

**To access the actual code examples**, you would need to visit the GitHub link mentioned or watch the accompanying video tutorial on the PremiereOnScript YouTube channel.
